##Huanggang, the battle for bed space in an epidemic

Wechat, renwumag1980

Feature Introduction, the best Chinese character report

The war on viruses is also a war on beds. On January 30, Tang Zhihong, director of the Huanggang Health Commission, was fired a day later after being asked by the inspection team how many beds there were in Huanggang. So, how many beds are there in Huanggang? How can we buy more time in this battle?

Wen | Yi Fangxing, Zheng Dan

Editor | Cho Ming

Sun Liang's mother is probably the most frequently transferred patient in Huanggang for new pneumonia.

She first became ill in early January and was admitted to Huanggang General Hospital. She was transferred to the ICU ward of the better-equipped Huangzhou District people's hospital because of a continuous high fever and a shadow over her lungs. More than a week later, she was diagnosed with new crown pneumonia and transferred again to the ICU ward of Huanggang City Centre Hospital, the only top three hospital in Huanggang. A week later, on Feb. 2, she was finally transferred to Dabie Mountains Medical Center, also known as Little Tangshan in Huanggang, Huanggang's new center for the treatment of confirmed patients. At this point, she's in critical condition.

In less than a month, the man, in his 70s, has been transferred to hospital three times and has been transferred to at least four beds. It was also a period of great increase in the number of confirmed cases in Huanggang, and also a time when the number of beds in Huanggang City did not "feel like an expansion" . The issue of beds was so important that it led directly to the dismissal of a Huanggang official.

Huanggang, the country's second most affected area after Wuhan, was once in short supply of beds. Guo Yinghu, vice chairman of the Huanggang Municipal Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, said that until January 21, there was not a single infectious disease hospital in the city that met the criteria, and that was why Sun Liang's mother was frequently transferred to another hospital. At least 1,818 beds were opened up in the urban area of Huanggang after the opening of the "little soup hill" in Huanggang.

Is this GONNA be enough? The number of infected is still rising. On February 5, the number of confirmed cases in Huanggang reached 1,645, of which 527 were in downtown Huanggang. The war on viruses is also a war on beds. The only way to win this war is to stay ahead of the virus.

![img](data:image/jpeg;base64,)
Dabie Mountains Regional Medical Center Ward Source Huanggang News Network

No infectious disease hospitals, no isolation beds

When exactly was the mother infected? Sun Liang thought long and hard.

He recalled that around January 13, his mother had been in hospital for more than a week, getting better, ready to leave the hospital, just the family happy new year. The diagnosis showed that the mother had high blood pressure and presented with cerebral infarction. For a 70-year-old man, cerebral infarction is a common disease, he does not worry about it.

Until a new patient came into the ward.

The patient coughed and vomited uncontrollably and spent the night in the ward until he was transferred the next day. On January 15, the mother, who was about to be released from the hospital, developed a low-grade fever, which quickly turned into a high fever lasting three days. CT showed a patchy, dense pattern in the mother's previously asymptomatic lungs.

"I later learned that there was pneumonia among the patients admitted to the Chinese Medicine Hospital at that time. However, even the doctors at that time probably did not know that it was new pneumonia. "since her mother had been in hospital for nearly half a month, Sun Liang speculated that she had contracted the disease while in hospital. One of the most likely sources of infection is the patient. Her mother had told Sun Liang that the doctors and nurses in her general ward, let alone the patients and their families, had no quarantine until she was transferred on Jan. 15.

Until Huanggang's decision to seal off the city on January 23rd, the city was virtually defenseless against the virus. As there are no infectious disease hospitals, most of the new pneumonia patients live in the general ward. Cross-infection occurs not only between patients, but also between health care workers.

In retrospect, the case of human-to-human transmission occurred in Huanggang before Academician Zhong Nanshan announced the new crown pneumonia. Zhao Qiu, a doctor at Huanggang's Central Hospital, said a pneumonia patient came to the hospital in early January and was later transferred to Wuhan. Since January 10, medical staff began to fall ill. "It started with a nurse named Dong Chunfeng, followed by a respiratory surgeon, and ended up infecting even the people who charged the hospital bills. A list of in-patients provided by Zhao Qiu shows that 21 hospital staff members were hospitalized due to infection from Dong Chunfeng's hospitalization on January 10 to the decision to open an infectious disease hospital on January 22. "At first, I didn't even wear a mask. It wasn't until the 20th or so that word got around in the hospital that I started wearing a mask every day. "

In a video interview later with Huanggang daily, Dong also admitted that the disease was not taken seriously at first. "On January 7, I had a fever and a cough. I didn't take it seriously. It was treated as a common cold. As a result, on January 10, she began chest tightness, breathing difficulties, continuous high fever, once unable to take care of herself and was admitted to the hospital.

22 days ago, the medical staff because of pneumonia in the hospital, at that time it was difficult to confirm. Guo Yinghu, vice chairman of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference (CPPCC) in Huanggang, said Huanggang had no right to test the new crown until January 19; by January 20-22, it had given up the right to do so, but there was no test reagent in Huanggang. It was not until January 23 that the test kits were in place that the tests could begin.

Undiagnosed and with no Infectious Disease Hospital, the early Huanggang Hospital had no beds to meet quarantine standards. "At that time, doctors and patients were in a state of defencelessness, " Dr. Zhao said. "

![img](data:image/jpeg;base64,)
Source: Huanggang News

360 beds were hastily cleared and quickly filled

Since January 21, the number of confirmed cases in Huanggang has remained at 12 for three consecutive days.

In contrast to the three-day constant number of confirmed cases, there has been a surge in the number of highly suspected cases. Because they weren't able to diagnose it, the unification was called viral pneumonia. On January 22,300 people were viral pneumonia in Huanggang, according to multiple sources.

He's not GonNa make it to the general ward. On January 21st, the day after the declaration of human-to-human transmission in Zhong Nanshan, Huanggang decided to open three emergency designated hospitals to isolate patients for three days, including an Infectious Disease Hospital, a Huimin County hospital that was originally a community hospital, and a senior-citizen apartment.

Huanggang has just given birth to its first segregated beds, 360 in all. Liu Cai, a nurse in the Department of Endocrinology at Huanggang Central Hospital, was ordered to transfer patients from the hospital to an infectious disease hospital starting at 3:30 p.m. on January 22.

Time is of the essence. They didn't even clean up the hospitals there until the 21st. After three days, after a simple cleaning, some equipment was installed. Liu Cai and about 80 medical staff from the Department of aspiration and endocrinology were officially transferred to the Infectious Disease Hospital. Over there, she saw a completely different structure from the normal ward, "one room, one window, where the nurse could put the medicine in every day to prevent cross-infection. "

On January 23rd, during the opening of three designated hospitals in Huanggang, Sun Liang discovered that his father, who had been nursing his mother in the ward, had also developed a high fever.

He took him for a CT scan, and his father's lungs showed signs of infection, a "ground-glass shadow, " one of the classic symptoms of neocoronary pneumonia. But at the time, Huanggang lacked the test to confirm the diagnosis. But under Huanggang's rules, only confirmed cases are admitted to designated hospitals.

Sun Liang went through three days of trying to find a room for her father. Took his father, who had a high fever, to the Infectious Diseases Hospital twice, and he couldn't even get through the door. They said they only take confirmed patients from the hospital. Then he had to wait in line with his father for a few hours, and went back to the fever clinic at the downtown hospital, hoping for a diagnosis. The doctor had no choice but to rule out the possibility of the flu, then sent him home to wait.

It was 24 days before the arrival of patients at Huanggang's fever clinic -- A walk through, then check for influenza a and B, and finally get word back home.

The city of Huanggang was closed on that day. From 00:00 on the 24th, public transport will be suspended in Huanggang, Metro stations, railway stations and all entertainment venues will be closed. The people of Huanggang were not really nervous until this moment. On that day, the number of confirmed cases in the city remained at 12.

Sun Liang's father was finally admitted to an Infectious Disease Hospital on January 25.

On the morning of the 25th, he received the news that his father had been diagnosed. Due to the decentralization of testing power, coupled with detection reagent gradually in place, Huanggang city CDC began testing. However, because the CDC has only one Q6 from the Abi, even at full capacity, detection efficiency remains low. Another piece of bad news is that testers are required to wear a level 3 protective gear, but by this time the level 3 protective equipment in the lab is empty and they have to turn to the community for help. Not only CDC, the lack of masks, protective clothing and other protective materials, as well as the city's hospitals.

The city of Huanggang, in just a few days, has suddenly been thrust into a situation of unprecedented difficulty.

![img](data:image/jpeg;base64,)
Photograph Courtesy Huanggang Daily News

1,818 beds, "Little Huanggang Hills" 

There's still not enough beds.

The number of people infected has further increased. As testing capacity improved, the number of confirmed cases in Huanggang rose sharply from 12 at the start of the year on January 25 to 122 on January 26 and 10 days later to 1,645.

There is not much time for policymakers to respond. On January 24th, just three days after a decision was made on January 21st to temporarily open three designated hospitals, Huanggang's city government again decided to urgently activate the unfinished Dabie Mountains Regional Medical Centre, the Huanggang version of Little Tangshan.

Dabie Mountains Medical Center wasn't built for an Infectious Disease Hospital. The first phase of the Dabie Mountains Medical Center, with an investment of 1.26 billion yuan, covers an area of 500 mu and 1,500 hospital beds. Construction started in 2016 and the main structure was capped in 2017. In May 2020, the entire Huanggang City Centre hospital was expected to be relocated to a general hospital.

It's very difficult to turn a general hospital into an Infectious Disease Hospital in three days. From the public photos can be seen, the isolation of the nurses station glass are temporary play of glass glue, some also affixed with transparent tape. At the beginning, the overall framework of the Dabie Mountains Medical Center was very simple, with nurses'stations and doctors'stations connected to wards and no contamination or buffer zones, China News weekly reported. But below, can use plastic board, plank to these passageways undertake simple partition only.

But there is good news. After learning of the Hubei outbreak, Shandong and Hunan set up two groups of medical teams to support Huanggang, with about 540 medical staff. The medical staff, who will be stationed at the Dabie Mountains medical centre, are from the relevant departments of the Department of aspiration and endocrinology. One member of the team called it "the march on Dabie Mountains. " .

To help the support medical team get acquainted with the local medical system, it was the local doctors in Huanggang. Dong Hu, a surgeon at the city center hospital, is one of them. At the time, the hospital was short-staffed, requiring all doctors with clinical experience to go to the Dabie Mountains Medical Center, where many had no experience with infectious diseases and did not even wear protective clothing.

We were called in by medical services, and none of us on call were reluctant to go there. "Dong Hu said. Three floors below Dabie Mountains Medical Center are used as auxiliary units. New Pneumonia patients are admitted from the fourth floor. When the fourth floor is full, the fifth floor is opened.

The hospital is divided into east and West wards with 110 to 120 beds on each floor. The number of beds is also gradually expanding. In the process, an out-of-town medical team brought hope to Huanggang.

![img](data:image/jpeg;base64,)
Paramedics prepare at the Regional Medical Center in Dabie Mountains, Huanggang

"We all play a bridging role to help them understand our computer-based healthcare system. Each floor is trained for three days and then taken over by an out-of-town team. From January 28, the official start, 4,5,6,7 floors of the ward has been opened. "

Meanwhile, the number of patients is still rising.

Dabie Mountains's entire four-story house, handed over to field teams, was soon filled. Patients from Huanggang's three previously designated hospitals, including Sun Liang's mother, were transferred here as part of the intensive care program.

"The problem is that there are not enough doctors in the out-of-town teams, and our own doctors are opening new wards. Next, Dong Hu will go to the second and third floors of the hospital to open future wards.

The number of beds in Huanggang is racing against the virus. On January 30, Tang Zhihong, director of the Huanggang Health Commission, was fired a day later after being asked by the inspection team how many beds there were in Huanggang.

So, how many beds are there in Huanggang? A day later, on January 31st, at a news conference in Huanggang, the answer was clear.

"Six sentinel sites and three standby units have been activated in the urban area of Huanggang, they are: Dabie Mountains Medical Center (1,000 beds, 576 rooms) , city infectious disease hospital (210 beds, 120 rooms) , Longwangshan senior citizens'apartment (90 beds, 56 rooms) , city Huimin Hospital (60 beds, 24 rooms) , Nanhu senior citizens'apartment (120 beds, 100 rooms) , secondary vocational training building (200 beds, 200 rooms) , the spare unit also has 350 rooms with a total capacity of 1,818 beds. The city has identified 29 designated hospitals can provide a total of 4200 beds, 2831 rooms. "said Guo Yinghu, vice-chairman of the Huanggang Municipal Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference.

Sun Liang's father died before he could get into Dabie Mountains Medical Center. In his grief, he looked forward to the day when his mother, lying in a hospital bed, would be healed and released.

![img](data:image/jpeg;base64,)
Source: Beijing News

Sun Liang, Zhao Qiu, Liu Cai and Dong Hu are aliases
